pullrequest.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

content.raw:
I guess what I was getting at is that BLACS on a local machine and BLACS on a remote machine are both special cases of BLACS on a some machine, so they should not be made different in implementation or syntax.

In the short term I think that my line of comments should be IGNORED, because it sounds like I think that there should be a difference between a dispatching mechanism that does not do any hardware (i.e., is not BLACS) and a series of BLACS "RemoteBLACS" instances both with and without the UI.  Right now BLACS combines these functions in a way that makes sense on one machine, but not with many.
content.html:
I guess what I was getting at is that BLACS on a local machine and BLACS on a remote machine are both special cases of BLACS on a some machine, so they should not be made different in implementation or syntax.

In the short term I think that my line of comments should be IGNORED, because it sounds like I think that there should be a difference between a dispatching mechanism that does not do any hardware (i.e., is not BLACS) and a series of BLACS "RemoteBLACS" instances both with and without the UI. Right now BLACS combines these functions in a way that makes sense on one machine, but not with many.

pull_request.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

update.description:
Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes for launching workers, BLACS tabs, etc. after discussions with Chris Billington

Some examples of use would be:

```python
# remote devices
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'rpi1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', '192.168.0.13', parent=raspberry_pi_1) # pi-2 on private network only accessible to pi-1
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_3', 'rpi3.physics.monash.edu')

# Connection Table
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n1', com_port='COM1', gui=raspberry_pi_1) # worker and GUI on same machine
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n2', com_port='COM1', gui=raspberry_pi_1, worker=raspberry_pi_2) # worker and GUI on separate remote machines
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n3', com_port='COM1', worker=raspberry_pi_3) # only worker on remote machine
```

These launch remote BLACS tabs and workers as appropriate \(and are automatically managed/restarted/etc by a zprocess based broker system under development by Chris Billington\). SecondaryControlSystem will be used to handle communication with other programs \(which could include BLACS theoretically\) that are not to be automatically managed, but require starting/restarting by the user manually.
update.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

content.raw: I'm +1 on this, and have no other comments about the current implementation. Making the tabs pop out will not be hard, to make use of more localhost screen real estate. They already do pop out in a sense, when you drag one outside the main BLACS window it is actually floating around with your mouse in a tiny tabwidget. Just need to make it go fullsize when you release it instead of back to where it was dragged from. Well. "just". more too it than that but not too much more.
content.html: I'm +1 on this, and have no other comments about the current implementation. Making the tabs pop out will not be hard, to make use of more localhost screen real estate. They already do pop out in a sense, when you drag one outside the main BLACS window it is actually floating around with your mouse in a tiny tabwidget. Just need to make it go fullsize when you release it instead of back to where it was dragged from. Well. "just". more too it than that but not too much more.

pullrequest.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

pull_request.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

pullrequest.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

content.raw:
There is actually already a device created for the local \(primary\) BLACS instance which becomes the parent of all the `RemoteBLACS` and `SecondaryControlSystem` "devices". This is an instance of the `_PrimaryBLACS` class, but is not really expected to be accessed by the user. 

It is also not automatically used for devices which don't explicitly specify a `gui` and `worker` kwarg. There are a couple of reasons for this:

* In order to maintain backwards compatibility between a version of BLACS that supports remote devices and HDF5 files produced by a version of labscript that does not, we need to make BLACS assume that devices missing `gui` and `worker` are attached to the primary instance \(only instance in this case\) of BLACS anyway. 
* We maintain forwards compatibility between new labscript \(supporting remote gui and workers\) and old BLACS, if you don't use any of the new features \(you are not required to recompile your BLACS connection table just to ensure that experiments are able to run\). 
* I suspect that we will have a tab in BLACS which provides the status of remote devices \(queried via the ZMQ command server or secondary control system\). This ultimately corresponds to the device in the connection table for the `_PrimaryBLACS` that is created internally. Importantly, this object is only placed in the connection table if you create a `RemoteBLACS` or `SecondaryControlSystem` device. This is useful in the situation where your BLACS connection table has many remote devices, but your compiled experiment is only using devices connected to the primary BLACS PC. If you remove the unused `RemoteBLACS` and `SecondaryControlSystem` definitions in your experiment logic connection table, the device for primary BLACS is not created  and the current architecture of the queue is already set up to then ignore unused/missing devices, in this case the tab \(and thus presumably communication\) with all remote devices.

While I'm not married to any particular class name, personally I think I prefer `RemoteBLACS` to `BlacsHost` simply because it makes it clear this is to run on a separate PC \(I think it unlikely we would have a second instance of BLACS on the same PC, mainly because the easier solution to that is just to add support for tabs that can pop-out of the main BLACS window\).
content.html:
There is actually already a device created for the local (primary) BLACS instance which becomes the parent of all the RemoteBLACS and SecondaryControlSystem "devices". This is an instance of the _PrimaryBLACS class, but is not really expected to be accessed by the user.

It is also not automatically used for devices which don't explicitly specify a gui and worker kwarg. There are a couple of reasons for this:

  • In order to maintain backwards compatibility between a version of BLACS that supports remote devices and HDF5 files produced by a version of labscript that does not, we need to make BLACS assume that devices missing gui and worker are attached to the primary instance (only instance in this case) of BLACS anyway.
  • We maintain forwards compatibility between new labscript (supporting remote gui and workers) and old BLACS, if you don't use any of the new features (you are not required to recompile your BLACS connection table just to ensure that experiments are able to run).
  • I suspect that we will have a tab in BLACS which provides the status of remote devices (queried via the ZMQ command server or secondary control system). This ultimately corresponds to the device in the connection table for the _PrimaryBLACS that is created internally. Importantly, this object is only placed in the connection table if you create a RemoteBLACS or SecondaryControlSystem device. This is useful in the situation where your BLACS connection table has many remote devices, but your compiled experiment is only using devices connected to the primary BLACS PC. If you remove the unused RemoteBLACS and SecondaryControlSystem definitions in your experiment logic connection table, the device for primary BLACS is not created and the current architecture of the queue is already set up to then ignore unused/missing devices, in this case the tab (and thus presumably communication) with all remote devices.

While I'm not married to any particular class name, personally I think I prefer RemoteBLACS to BlacsHost simply because it makes it clear this is to run on a separate PC (I think it unlikely we would have a second instance of BLACS on the same PC, mainly because the easier solution to that is just to add support for tabs that can pop-out of the main BLACS window).

content.raw:
Phil, this looks like a great change!  How do you like:

    BlacsHost(...) 

rather than

    RemoteBLACS(...)

Since it doesn't actually have to be a remote host, it could be local.  I guess I am asking should this line be mandatory even for the local host?  Or should by default a call like (using your current syntax):

    RemoteBLACS('localhost', 'localhost')

be implied, with gui and worker defaulting to 'localhost' in all device definitions?
content.html:
Phil, this looks like a great change! How do you like:

BlacsHost(...)

rather than

RemoteBLACS(...)

Since it doesn't actually have to be a remote host, it could be local. I guess I am asking should this line be mandatory even for the local host? Or should by default a call like (using your current syntax):

RemoteBLACS('localhost', 'localhost')

be implied, with gui and worker defaulting to 'localhost' in all device definitions?

The other question is not applicable any more because I've completely changed the syntax/way it works in the last commit :slight_smile:

Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes for launching workers, BLACS tabs, etc. after discussions with Chris Billington

Some examples of use would be:

```python
# remote devices
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'rpi1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', '192.168.0.13', parent=raspberry_pi_1) # pi-2 on private network only accessible to pi-1
```

These launch remote BLACS tabs and workers as appropriate \(and are automatically managed/restarted/etc by a zprocess based broker system under development by Chris Billington\). pull_request.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

pullrequest.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

content.raw:
Hi Ian,

I've taken your comments on board and updated the pull request. The initial reason for the nested syntax proposed was so that we could represent arbitrarily complex network topologies \(which many labs are unable to control due to institution wide enforced IT policies\).

In order to keep this feature, and use the flatter syntax you \(and others\) propose, I am now moving the definition of the network hierarchy into the definitions of the `RemoteBLACS`objects in much the same way that we do when defining the hierarchy of devices via their clocking signals.

As such, the interface now becomes:

```python
# remote devices
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'rpi1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', '192.168.0.13', parent=raspberry_pi_1) # pi-2 on private network only accessible to pi-1
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_3', 'rpi3.physics.monash.edu')

# Connection Table
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n1', com_port='COM1', gui=raspberry_pi_1) # worker and GUI on same machine
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n2', com_port='COM1', gui=raspberry_pi_1, worker=raspberry_pi_2) # worker and GUI on separate remote machines
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n3', com_port='COM1', worker=raspberry_pi_3) # only worker on remote machine
```

This syntax also has additional benefits such as allowing us to explicitly enforce that the worker is a child \(as far as the network topology goes\) of the GUI and makes it clear \(hopefully\) that hostnames of remote PCs should be specified as the external hostname \(and port\) that the parent should connect on.
content.html:
Hi Ian,

I've taken your comments on board and updated the pull request. The initial reason for the nested syntax proposed was so that we could represent arbitrarily complex network topologies (which many labs are unable to control due to institution wide enforced IT policies).

In order to keep this feature, and use the flatter syntax you (and others) propose, I am now moving the definition of the network hierarchy into the definitions of the RemoteBLACSobjects in much the same way that we do when defining the hierarchy of devices via their clocking signals.

As such, the interface now becomes:

# remote devices
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'rpi1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', '192.168.0.13', parent=raspberry_pi_1) # pi-2 on private network only accessible to pi-1
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_3', 'rpi3.physics.monash.edu')

# Connection Table
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n1', com_port='COM1', gui=raspberry_pi_1) # worker and GUI on same machine
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n2', com_port='COM1', gui=raspberry_pi_1, worker=raspberry_pi_2) # worker and GUI on separate remote machines
NovaTechDDS9m(name='n3', com_port='COM1', worker=raspberry_pi_3) # only worker on remote machine

This syntax also has additional benefits such as allowing us to explicitly enforce that the worker is a child (as far as the network topology goes) of the GUI and makes it clear (hopefully) that hostnames of remote PCs should be specified as the external hostname (and port) that the parent should connect on.

pull_request.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

update.description:
Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes for launching workers, BLACS tabs, etc. after discussions with Chris Billington

Some examples of use would be:

```python
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', 'pi-2.physics.monash.edu')

NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', com_port = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteWorker('COM1'))
NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', com_port = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI('COM2'))
NovaTechDDS9m('nt3', com_port = 
    raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI(raspberry_pi_2.RemoteWorker('COM1')))
```

These launch remote BLACS tabs and workers as appropriate \(and are automatically managed/restarted/etc by a zprocess based broker system under development by Chris Billington\). SecondaryControlSystem will be used to handle communication with other programs \(which could include BLACS theoretically\) that are not to be automatically managed, but require starting/restarting by the user manually.
update.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

pull_request.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

pullrequest.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

content.raw:
I love the idea of launching devices present on remote hardware, but I have to say that the proposed syntax looks complicated and counter-intuitive.

In most cases, I would think that I would support the much more transparent syntax:

Most transparent and logical extension to labscript:

    NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', com_port = 'COM1', host='pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
    NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', com_port = 'COM2', host='pi-2.physics.monash.edu')

or perhaps a more flexible, somewhat less clear syntax:

    RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
    RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', 'pi-2.physics.monash.edu')
    NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', com_port='COM1', host=raspberry_pi_1.RemoteWorker)
    NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', com_port='COM2', host=raspberry_pi_2.RemoteGUI)

or [but I don't like this one as it is pretty opaque]:

    RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
    RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', 'pi-2.physics.monash.edu')

    NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', host = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteWorker('COM1'))
    NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', host = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI('COM2'))
    NovaTechDDS9m('nt3', host = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI(raspberry_pi_2.RemoteWorker('COM1')))


It seems to me that using the com_port to denote the remote blacs might be a very nice technical solution, but it is really unfriendly.
content.html:
I love the idea of launching devices present on remote hardware, but I have to say that the proposed syntax looks complicated and counter-intuitive.

In most cases, I would think that I would support the much more transparent syntax:

Most transparent and logical extension to labscript:

NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', com_port = 'COM1', host='pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', com_port = 'COM2', host='pi-2.physics.monash.edu')

or perhaps a more flexible, somewhat less clear syntax:

RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', 'pi-2.physics.monash.edu')
NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', com_port='COM1', host=raspberry_pi_1.RemoteWorker)
NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', com_port='COM2', host=raspberry_pi_2.RemoteGUI)

or [but I don't like this one as it is pretty opaque]:

RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_1', 'pi-1.physics.monash.edu')
RemoteBLACS('raspberry_pi_2', 'pi-2.physics.monash.edu')

NovaTechDDS9m('nt1', host = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteWorker('COM1'))
NovaTechDDS9m('nt2', host = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI('COM2'))
NovaTechDDS9m('nt3', host = raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI(raspberry_pi_2.RemoteWorker('COM1')))

It seems to me that using the com_port to denote the remote blacs might be a very nice technical solution, but it is really unfriendly.

`RemoteGUI` makes sense if it is just the GUI :slight_smile: 

Ok so `SecondaryControlSystem` will be embedded in to BLACS with some callbacks and \(yet to be\) defined communication protocoll?

 Is there a application for calling `RemoteBLACS`? As it is of type `_RemoteConnection` it is theoretically callable.
content.html:
RemoteGUI makes sense if it is just the GUI

Ok so SecondaryControlSystem will be embedded in to BLACS with some callbacks and (yet to be) defined communication protocoll?

Is there a application for calling RemoteBLACS? As it is of type _RemoteConnection it is theoretically callable.

pull_request.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

pullrequest.title: Updates to RemoteWorker and similar classes

content.raw:
To answer your questions:

* `raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI` by itself implies that the worker is on the same machine as the GUI \(but that it is remote to the primary instance of BLACS\). The alternative would be to have the worker on a separate PC again \(see the third example above\) in which case communication for coordinating the shot goes from the primary BLACS to the remote GUI to the remote worker.  
    
  Please feel free to suggest other names for `RemoteGUI`, we just couldn't come up with anything better at the time.
* `SecondaryControlSystem` is to indicate that the GUI \(and worker, although that could be chained with `RemoteWorker` in order to shift the worker somewhere else if that made sense\) is for control systems that work like our imaging system BIAS. In a way it's aim is to be like a generalised version of the `Camera` class in the sense that there is a tab in BLACS that mediates the communication to another program \(that's likely running on another computer\). The distinction between this and `RemoteGUI` is that the software that makes up your secondary control system should be launched manually by the user \(and so can be anything that conforms to the specifications\) where as `RemoteGUI` and `RemoteWorker` are assumed to be directly running the BLACS tab and BLACS worker code and will be managed by the upcoming zprocess command server \(aka a generalised version of the remote worker broker that will be built into zprocess\). Otherwise there is not much difference. We basically introduced it to distinguish between remote GUIs that were managed by the user and those that were managed remotely by primary BLACS \(aka restarted when connection table is recompiled, etc.\)

Does that help to clarify? Happy to expand more on our thought process today if you wish!
content.html:
To answer your questions:

  • raspberry_pi_1.RemoteGUI by itself implies that the worker is on the same machine as the GUI (but that it is remote to the primary instance of BLACS). The alternative would be to have the worker on a separate PC again (see the third example above) in which case communication for coordinating the shot goes from the primary BLACS to the remote GUI to the remote worker.

Please feel free to suggest other names for RemoteGUI, we just couldn't come up with anything better at the time. * SecondaryControlSystem is to indicate that the GUI (and worker, although that could be chained with RemoteWorker in order to shift the worker somewhere else if that made sense) is for control systems that work like our imaging system BIAS. In a way it's aim is to be like a generalised version of the Camera class in the sense that there is a tab in BLACS that mediates the communication to another program (that's likely running on another computer). The distinction between this and RemoteGUI is that the software that makes up your secondary control system should be launched manually by the user (and so can be anything that conforms to the specifications) where as RemoteGUI and RemoteWorker are assumed to be directly running the BLACS tab and BLACS worker code and will be managed by the upcoming zprocess command server (aka a generalised version of the remote worker broker that will be built into zprocess). Otherwise there is not much difference. We basically introduced it to distinguish between remote GUIs that were managed by the user and those that were managed remotely by primary BLACS (aka restarted when connection table is recompiled, etc.)

Does that help to clarify? Happy to expand more on our thought process today if you wish!

content.raw:
Ok so I have questions:

* Does using `RemoteBLACS.RemoteGUI`mean that the worker and GUI are remote? I find the naming of `RemoteGUI` quite confusing. 
* I'm not sure of the role of `SecondaryControlSystem` after these changes. Is this supposed to be subclassed by a device to handle the communication on the local side? Could you think of a case where it would be needed and maybe step me through on exactly how you imagine this would be used? I can currently only think of moving gui and worker to another machine which is now covered by `RemoteBLACS` as I understand it.
content.html:
Ok so I have questions:

  • Does using RemoteBLACS.RemoteGUImean that the worker and GUI are remote? I find the naming of RemoteGUI quite confusing.
  • I'm not sure of the role of SecondaryControlSystem after these changes. Is this supposed to be subclassed by a device to handle the communication on the local side? Could you think of a case where it would be needed and maybe step me through on exactly how you imagine this would be used? I can currently only think of moving gui and worker to another machine which is now covered by RemoteBLACS as I understand it.
